column4: Quick question, does the Live CD use gksudo (I am writing a guide)?
full-fledge GNOME desktop uses "gksu(do)"
Is it installed in the Live CD's system though?
run it from the terminal, you'll see
I don;t have the Live CD, that's why I'm asking :)
yes
Mainly because WINE Is Not an Emulator :)
It is useful, but I try to use only FLOSS and most FLOSS has Linux ports

I think that programs should be able to run on any machine, even if it involves emulation. That is why I respect Apple whenever they switch architecture (at least they DO switch architecture, unlike one company I could name)
backslash is an abomination in a filesystem
update the plugin list using KDE control panel
Amarok takes a while to respond when changing tracks to a musepack file (around 2 seconds to display OSD etc.)
Nope. Everything else is Mp3 and OGG with no problems
maybe it's the plugin itself
I think it may either be from a) not very well supported format or b) musepack is such a complex/compressed format it is inevitable
Lossy
I think it is "open", but based on MP3 so it can't be technically
If it was lossless then I would simply convert to FLAC, but it is a bad idea to transcode lossy to lossy
I would guess it's the algorithm
Well I can speculate, but I was just curious about peaople's real-world experience with it. I may test it in XMMS, since that is more lightweight
It doesn't affect quality thankfully
Hmmm... XMMS seems to have no gap when changing tracks. In fact, it seems to change tracks 4 seconds before the song is over :(
it is still GPL'd
So installing it in VMWare has no restrictions or seperate licence issues?
